com.wm.xmldata

Class XmlData

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.wm.xmldata.XmlData

  • public class XmlData
extends java.lang.Object

    See glossary of terms

    XmlData versus the legacy XML IData infoset encoding

    The XmlData feature encodes the XML Infoset as IData structures using a format similar to, but more advanced than the legacy format of prior encoding implementations. The structure of the raw IData itself is completely unaffected by this feature and in theory any IData implementation could be used as a basis for the XmlData infoset encoding. Rather, this feature adds a layer of formalism to the way in which XML infosets are represented using IData. This new format is independent of the prior legacy implementation format; the legacy implementation, services, and applications that use the legacy format continue to function without change. The new format is exploited using a separate set of public services and helper classes. In addition, XmlData Document Types generated from schemas have a somewhat different format. The two formats (both instance data and Document Types) cannot be intermixed. The XmlData infoset format should not reference the legacy infoset format, and legacy XML format should not reference XmlData infoset format. However, either or both types of format can be referenced from an IData that does not represent XML encoded data (for example the Integration Server pipeline or a variable in the pipeline). The two types cannot be mixed because they represent tags using completely different and incompatible techniques. The XmlData format supports XML schema features not supported by the legacy format. This support includes repeating model groups, substitution groups, and 'any' wildcards.

    The XmlData Infoset Encoding

    Like the legacy approach, XmlData uses IData objects to represent complex content as tag-object-pairs. Likewise, it uses Strings to represents simple content, and uses IData to represent complex content (content with child elements). Also, as in the legacy approach, repeating tags in the instance XML(corresponding to schema elements with minOccurs > 1) are represented as a single tag paired with an array of items. However, the XmlData format supports no object type other than String, IData, or arrays of them; not even Java null is allowed. Empty simple content must be represented as empty Strings and empty complex content must be represented as empty IData objects.

    The encoding format conforms to the format of the new XmlData Document Types, though it is possible to use XmlData without Document Types. XmlData does not operate with legacy Document Types created from schemas. The new XmlData Document Types more fully represent the capabilities of XML and XML Schema. When conforming Document Types are not used, a slightly simpler infoset encoding format is used.

    The new XmlData format is created from XML and converted back to XML using new services in the pub.xmldata folder of the WmPublic package. This makes it possible for Flow Map manipulation of the new format in ways very similar to the legacy format.

    Within a Java application, all manipulation of the XmlData infoset should be accomplished using this class, XmlDataCursor, XmlDataTreeCursor, or one the helper classes such as XmlDataMap or XmlDataCopy. Direct manipulation of the XmlData infoset using raw IData methods is strongly discouraged, as it may make applications vulnerable to future changes in the XmlData infoset necessitated by enhancements or bug fixes.

    When conforming XmlData Document Types are used, the encoding uses four types of items: simple-values, group-values, complex-values, and when substitution groups or any particle are present in the source schema, indirect-items. When Document Types are not used to direct the encoding, no indirect-items are present in the XmlData infoset; the infoset contains only one of the three types of values.

    A simple-value is represented as a Java String. It represents a schema simpleType and as such has no sub-components, it stands alone.

    A group-value is an IData collection of tag-object-pairs. Group-values correspond roughly to schema model groups. The objects may be simple-values, group-values, complex-values, indirect-items, or arrays of thom. When a schema complexType has no attributes and no repeating top-level group, it is represented as a group-value. This simplifies the presentation of such complexTypes by removing the clutter of unnecessary *attributes fields and group-tags that are present in a complex-value.

    Complex-values are specialized IData structures that are used if schema complexTypes have attributes or repeating top-level groups. They may have a *attributes field paired with an attribute-set and they may also have a content-pair. The content-pair may be simple-value paired with a *simple tag or or a group-value paired with a group-tag. When the content is a simple-value, it corresponds to the schema simpleContent of a complexType. When the content is a group-value it corresponds to the top-level group of schema complexType with complexContent. Just as with a schema top-level group, the group-value may be repeating. In order to simplify Doctype rendering, a complexTypes with a non-repeating top-level group and no attributes is represented directly as a Doctype without a distinct attribute or content child, and its content is represented as a group-value.

    Indirect-items are specialized items that represent values expressed in an indirect way. There are two kinds of indirect items: substitution-items, and any-items. The indirect representation of these values makes the Java API a bit more complex than might be desired, but it allows a more straight-forward visual representation in Document Types and Flow Maps.

    If the tag is not repeating, then the object is a single item. If the tag is repeating (schema maxOccurs > 1) then the object is an array of item. When conforming Document Types are used, the array type matches the value type. Repeating simple-values are represented as String[], repeating group-values, complex-values and indirect-items are represented as IData[], and repeating anyTypes are represented as Object[]. When conforming Document Types are not used, all repeating values are represented as Object[]s.

    In a more obvious departure from the legacy format, the tag has a very specialized format. The tag is comprised of several components: a particle-id, a local name, and an optional namespace. The particle-id allows repeated occurrence of a name in a model to be uniquely identified. The repeated occurrence is not relative to the maxOccurs attribute, rather it identifies the repeated use of the same tag at different locations in a model. The XmlData feature encodes QNames as {particleId}ncName#namespaceURI rather than prefix:ncName. This eliminates the need for and complexity of a disjoint definition of the namespace elsewhere such as in a Document Type or in an instance nsDecls map. The particle-id ensures that Flow Map references to a particular tag remain unambiguous, even if the tags are created out of order.

    There are four types of content-tags: element-tags, group-tags, any-tags, and ssubstitution-tags. On a historical note, the legacy form of IData encoding for XML only has element tags. Also, when XmlData is used without a conforming Document Type, only element-tags are present (a top-level group-tag may be present in a complex-value).

    • element-tags are Strings with format {particle-id}localName#namespace and have associated element values (simple-values, group-values, or complex-values, or arrays of them)
    • group-tags are Strings with format {particle-id}*group and have associated group-values (or arrays of them)
    • substitution-tags are Strings of the form {particle-id}*substitution-localName#namespace and have associated substitution-item values (a specialized IData structure)
    • any-tags are Strings with format {particle-id}*any and have associated any-items (a specialized IData structure)

    Collectively, the four tag types mentioned above are called content-tags because they appear in content models. There is a one-to-one correspondence between content-tags and particles in a schema content model. Each schema 'element' particle has a corresponding element-tag. Each schema 'any' particle has a corresponding any-tag. Each schema substitution group head has a corresponding substitution-tag, and each schema 'group' has a correspond group-tag.

    Some content items have specialized structure. any-tags have associated any-items with a specialized structure that contains the NCName, Namespaces, and a value member that references the actual value. This indirect representation allows Flow Maps to manipulate both wildcard name and its value. substitution-tags also have associated substitution-item with a specialized structure. This indirect representation allows Flow Maps to present all of the possible members of a substitution group. The item contain an IData that contains the actual instance tag-object-pair.

    Document Type aware XmlData

    Using a simple example, the XML content: 
        <inv:address xmlns:inv="www.invoice.com">555 Mockingbird Lane</inv:address>
    is represented in the legacy format using IData as key/value pair: 
        "inv:address" :: "555 Mockingbird Lane"
    with the prefix "inv" being defined externally, while in the new XmlData format, it is represented as an IData key/value pair: 
        "address#www.invoice.com" :: "555 Mockingbird Lane"

    When creating Document Types from schemas, model groups (sequence, choice, and all) are represented using a field named *group (i.e. a group-tag) with a field type of Document. The Document Type contains the child content definition of the group. When complex-values have attributes, the attributes are encoded under a separate Document containing the attributes. This separate IData value has a key named *attributes. If simple content is present with attributes, it is encoded using the key *simple. If a schema contains an any wildcard, that particle is represented as a field with an any-tag {particleId}*any and a content of Document. The Document content is a very specialized any-object format described later. If a schema contains substitution groups, the head of a substitution group is encoded as field with substitution-tag *substitution-name with a very specialized IData content that is described later.

    Finally, the members of model groups are further qualified by a leading particle-id of the form {1}, {2}, ... etc. This prefix uniquely identifies particles in a group since more than one particle with the same name can appear throughout a content model. Such qualification applies to group-tags, any-tags, substitution-tags, and element-tags, and is present even when the names are not repeated. This qualification is in addition to element repetition. For example, an element named "student" might have a maxOccurs property of 5 in one part of a content model and a maxOccurs property of 1 at some later point in the model. Thus, the first occurrence {1}student is defined as an array while the second occurrence {2}student is a scalar. In similar fashion, a content model might contain two choice groups. The first choice group is defined by a field with name {1}*group while the second choice group is defined by a field named {2}*group.

    These examples illustrate the encoding. For clarity, unqualified names as used, though th same layout is used for qualified names.

    Simple String content such as: 

         <name>kilroy</name>
    is encoded as a single IData key/value pair with the value being a simple String: 
        IData
      "{1}name" :: "kilroy"
    Note that the name field has been prefixed with {1} to denote the first occurrence of the element in the content. More complex content such as 
         <people xmlns:family>
        <brother>Sam</brother>
        <sister>Karen</sister>
        <brother>Bill</brother>
     </people>
    is encoded in a similar way with multiple tag-object-pairs: 
         "{1}people#family" :: IData
        "{1}brother#family" :: "Sam"
        "{1}sister#family"  :: "Karen"    
        "{2}brother#family" :: "Bill"
    Note that field names such as {1}brother#family include the XML namespace. Also note there there are distinct occurrences of the brother#family element each with a unique prefix. However, if content contains adjacent repeating elements, the content is represented as an array. 
         <people xmlns:family>
        <brother>Sam</brother>
        <brother>Bill</brother>
        <sister>Karen</sister>
     </people>
    is encoded in a somewhat similar way, but uses a String[] for the repeated value 
         "{1}people#family" :: IData
        "{1}brother#family" :: String[]
           "Sam"
           "Bill"
        "{1}sister#family"  :: "Karen"
    Content with attributes such as: 
           
     <item size="medium" color="blue">
        <supplier>ABC Inc.</supplier>
        <distributor> XYZ Inc.</distributor>
     </item>
    is encoded as two separate sub-documents named *attributes and *group 
        "item" :: IData
       "*attributes" :: IData
          "size" :: "medium"
          "color" :: "blue"
       "{1}*group" :: IData
          "{1}supplier" :: "ABC Inc."
          "{1}distributor" :: "XYZ Inc."
    when an element has attributes but only simple content, such as 
      
     <item size="medium" color="blue">shoe</item>
    the simple content is encoded as a *simple key/value pair rather than a *group sub-document 
        "item :: IData
       "*attributes" :: IData
          "size" :: "medium"
       "*simple" :: "shoe"

    In the preceding examples, the group-tag and group-value was present only when attributes were also present. Otherwise, the group-tags are not typically needed when only child elements are present. However, if an element has maxOccurs > 1 and its top level model group also has maxOccurs > 1, it is necessary that the group-tag be present because both the element and the group-values have repeating values stored as arrays. For example, given this XML document, 

         <employees>
        <name>Sam</name>
        <address>Mars</address>
        <name>Mary</name>
        <address>Venus</address>
     </employees>
     <employees>
        <name>George</name>
        <address>Pluto</address>
        <name>Sally</name>
        <address>Saturn</address>
     </employees>
    if employees is defined as a particle with maxOccurs > 1 and it content model is defined as multiple repetitions of name and address, then the IData representation of the XML is: 
        "employees" :: IData[]
        [0] IData 
            "*group" :: IData[]
                [0] IData
                    "name" :: "Sam"
                    "address" :: "Mars"
                [1] IData
                    "name" :: "Mary"
                    "address" :: "Venus"
        [1] IData       
            "*group" :: IData[]
                [0] IData
                    "name" :: "George"
                    "address" :: "Pluto"
                [1] IData
                    "name" :: "Sally"
                    "address" :: "Saturn"
    There are two schema features that make it impossible to know the tag names of values when Document Types are created from schemas. The first is the any wildcard. The other is the substitution group.

    The any wildcard is a placeholder for element names that re not determined until an instance document is parsed. In order to facilitate access and manipulation from Flow, the any wildcard is represented as a Document with fields named ncName, namespace, and value. This makes it possible for Flow programs to access or change both the name and the value of an XmlData tag-object-pairs that correspond to any wildcards.

    The substitution group allows a element to replace another element. It is, in a sense, the element equivalent to type derivation. In order to facilitate access and manipulation from Flow, a substitution group is represented as a head-of-group-element, with children that correspond to the elements that can replace the head. For example, an element named "vehicle" might be the head of a group that includes "car", "truck", and "bus". The Document Type that represents the group is: 

        {1}substitution-vehicle  [Document Type, choice model]
          {1}car             [Field]
          {1}truck           [Field]
          {1}bus             [Field
    The Document Type has a choice model group because only one of the substitution members can be present. This structure implies that the head of a group is modeled as group with IData content even when the head is simple type in the corresponding schema.

    Non Document Type aware XmlData

    It is possible to use XmlData without following the Document Type model. When no Document Types are in use, it is not possible to manipulate XmlData from Flow. It is also not possible to validate the content. When Document Types are not used, there are no wildcards, substitution heads, or model groups. Therefore, it is not necessary, or even possible to create wildcard, group, or substitution content when not using Document Types. In addition, the public services always represent repeating content as Object[] when Document Types are not in use. This greatly simplifies the use of XmlData whenDocument Types are not used, .

    Glossary of terms:

    Unfortunately, these definitions tend to be somewhat circular because XML and schema are also defined in a circular manner.
    • any-item - a specialized IData structure that contains content that corresponds to a schema 'any' wildcard particle. Any-items are always paired with an any-tag in a group-value. An any-item contains the following fields:
      • *ncName -- the local name portion of the XML infoset tag and content that corresponds to the 'any' particle.
      • *namespace -- the namespace portion of the XML infoset tag and content that corresponding to the 'any' particle.
      • *value -- the content portion of the XML infoset tag and content that corresponds to the 'any' particle. The value must be a scalar and must be either a simple-value, group-value, complex-value, or substitution-item.
      Any-items can be created using the createAnyItem(XmlDataElementTag, Object) method.
    • any-tag - a content-tag used to name the item that corresponds to an any particle in the schema model. There is generally a one-to-one correspondence between an any particles in a schema content model and any-tags. Any-tags are indirect-tags because there ts no actual tag in the XML instance with that name. They are paired with any-items which contain the actual tag and value as it appears in the XML instance.
      Its form is: {particle-id}*any where:
      • particle-id -- is the particle-id that uniquely identifies the any wildcard in a model
      Any-tags can be created and parsed using the XmlDataAnyTag class.
    • attribute-set - an IData containing tag-object-pairs. The tags are always attribute-tags and the values are always simple-values. The user never accesses this IData directly using an IDataCursor; instead XmlDataCursor or XmlData helper methods are used.. Attribute-sets are only ever referenced from a complex-value. Attribute-sets may be created using the createAttributes(Object...) method.
    • attribute-tag - a tag used to identify individual attributes in an attribute-set. Because attribute names must ne unique and order-independent, attribute-tags do not have a particle-id (they are not content-tags). Attribute-tags may be created and parsed using the XmlDataAnyTag class.
    • complex-value-content - the content portion of a complex-value. Complex-values are represented as IData objects that contain two optional members: the attribute-set and the complex-value-content. The complex-value-content is essentially the part of a complex-value that does not include the attribute-set. It is either the *simple tag paired with a simple-value, or a group-tag paired with either a group-value or an array of group-values.
    • complex-value - an IData structure that is used when an XML schema defines a type that contains attributes, a repeating top-level model group, or both. It is essentially an IData with two components: an attribute-set and complex-value-content. Attributes are represented as a *attribute field name paired with the attribute-set. Complex-value-content is represented as either a group-tag paired with a group-value or a *simple field name paired with a simple-value. When a schema complexType does not have attributes or a repeating top-level group, the XML infoset is represented using a group-value rather than a complex-value. Complex-values are always paired with an element-tag as a member of a group-value, or are referenced from within an any-item. This is because ultimately only an element can reference a complex value. A complex-value may be created using the createComplexValue() method.
    • conforming-XmlData-infoset - an XmlData infoset created using XmlData Document Types as a model. XmlData Document Types are created from XML schemas and preserve schema constructs such as repeating and nested model groups, element and attribute wildcards, and substitution groups. In addition to using XmlData element-tags and attribute-tags to represent XML infoset tags, conforming XmlData infosets also uses specialized tags such as group-tags, any-tags, and substitution-tags. to represent the special schema features. The specialized tags only appear in the conforming XMlData infoset (they do not appear in the original XML infoset which has only attribute tags and element tags).
    • content-tag - a (String) tag that is paired with an item as a member of a group-value. Content-tags always have a prefix particle-id in the form {n} in full-name format. This allows multiple occurrences of the same tag name to be uniquely identified within a group model. element-tags, group-tags, substitution-tags and any-tags are types of content-tags because they can appear as a tag-object-pair in a group-value. When using path-name format in map-paths or copy-paths, content-tags may contain addition information such an index and an indirect-qualifier.
    • copy-path - a path used by XmlDataCopy to specify the source and destination in an XmlData infoset. Each tag in a copy-path uniquely identifies a corresponding tag in the XmlData infoset, describing the path that is navigated during copy. Unlike map-paths, the tags in a copy-path may have place holders for names or indexes allowing a given step to apply to multiple values. These place holders are called iterator-tags. A copy-path may be created or parsed using the XmlDataPath class.
    • element-tag - a content-tag used to represent the element tag from an XML infoset. There is generally a one-to-one correspondence between element tags in an XML infoset and element-tags in an XmlData infoset.
      Its form is {particleId}ncName#namespace where:
      • particleId is the particle-id starting at 1
      • ncName is the XML local name
      • namespace is the XML namespace
      Element-tags may be created and parsed by using the XmlDataElementTag class.
    • full-name - a tag as it appears in an XmlData infoset. For content-tags, the full-name includes the particle-id, ncName, and namespace. It does not include an index or indirect-qualifier. For attribute-tags and type-tags, it includes only the ncName and namespace, but never a particle-id. The full-name of a tag may be obtained by using the XmlDataTag.getFullName() method on an instance of a parsed-tag such as an instance of XmlDataElementTag, XmlDataAttributeTag, XmlDataGroupTag, XmlDataAnyTag, XmlDataSubstitutionTag, or XmlDataTypeTag
    • group-tag -- a content-tag that is always paired with a group-value. For each group model in a schema, there will be a corresponding group-tag paired with a a group-value in the XmlData infoset.
      Its form is: {particleId}*group where:
      • particleId -- is the particle-id
      Group-tags may be created an parsed by using the XmlDataGroupTag class.
    • group-value - an IData containing tag-object-pairs. It corresponds roughly to schema model group content. The tags in a group-value will always be content-tags: element, group, any, or substitution. Group values may be created using the createGroupValue(Object...) method. They may also be manipulated by obtaining an XmlDataCursor for a group-value using the getXmlDataCursor(IData) method and then using the various cursor methods to navigate the group-value, adding, deleting, or modifying members of the group-value.
    • index - a non-negative integer offset into a repeating value. It is expressed as a String and enclosed in brackets when it is part a path-name. For example, {1}able#epsilon.org[3] addresses the 4th value in the array paired with content-tag {1}able#epsolon.org. The index never appears as part of the full-name, which is the tag as it appears in an XmlData infoset. It only appears as part of a path-name as used in a map-path or a copy-path.
    • index-iterator - an iterator-tag used as a place holder for an index in a copy-path. Iterator-tags may be created or parsed by using the XmlDataIteratorTag class.
    • indirect-item - a collective term for values that are indirectly named and referenced; they include substitution-items and any-items. The value-tag is embedded in the indirect-item along with the value. For example, an any-item is an IData with fields named *ncName, *namespace, and *value. The any-item corresponds to an any particle in a schema content model. The actual value associated with the any particle is paired with the *value tag. The value-tag is derived from the values paired with *ncName and *namespace.
    • indirect-qualifier - a content-tag used to name the content of an indirect-item. substitution-tags and any-tags are indirect-tags and do not directly name their content. The indirect-qualifier is a tag that is present in the indirect-item that names the value as it appears in the corresponding XML infoset. Indirect-qualifiers are typically used in conjunction with XmlDataMap paths when it is necessary to specify the value-tag for an indirect-item.
    • indirect-tag - substitution-tags and any-tags are indirect-tags. There is no actual content in the source XML infoset with these names. Instead these tags are paired with an indirect-item that contains the actual infoset name and content.
    • item - a scalar value or scalar indirect-item. If it is necessary to store more than one item at a tag (repeating-values), then an array of items is stored at the tag and it is necessary to provide an index to identify the desired item.
    • iterator-tag - a specialized symbolic tag used as a place holder for names, indexes, and qualifiers in the path-names of a copy-path. There are three types of iterator-tags:
      • index-iterator - used as a place holder for an index in a path-name of a cop-path
      • name-iterator - used as a place holder for the full-name in a path-name of a cop-path
      • qualifier-iterator - used as a placeholder for the indirect-qualifier in a path-name of a cop-path
      Iterator-tags may be created or parse using the XmlDataIteratorTag class.
    • map-path - a path used to map a descendant child of a value. Each tag in a map-path uniquely identifies a corresponding tag in the XmlData infoset, describing the path that is navigated.
    • name-iterator - an iterator-tag used as a place holder for a full-name in a copy-path.
    • nonconforming-XmlData-infoset - an XmlData infoset created without using Document Types as a model. Nonconforming XmlData infosets utilize only element-tags and attribute-tag. They do not contain group-tags (except as a solitary top-level member of a complex-value), any-tags, or substitution-tags. Nonconforming infosets always use Object[] to represent repeating values.
    • parsed-tag - an XmlData tag in its parsed form. When tags are present in the XmlData infoset, they always appear as Strings. The String form of XmlData tags can be rather complex and difficult to construct and manipulate. A set of helper classes (subclasses of XmlDataTag) is used to construct and manipulate tags as a collection of component parts. These subclasses are XmlDataElementTag, XmlDataAttributeTag, XmlDataGroupTag, XmlDataAnyTag, and XmlDataSubstitutionTag. These classes have constructors that accept the various component parts of a tag: ncName, namespace, and particle-id. They also have methods such as getFullName() and getPathName() that construct the complete form of the tag as a String. Many XmlData classes expect tags in parsed form (a subclass of XmlDataTag) rather than String form.
    • partial-name - a Java String. A tag-name without the particle-id. For content-tags, it's the full-name minus the {particle-id} prefix.
    • particle-id - a Java String. The particle-id is an incrementing integer starting at 1 that uniquely identifies a particles of the same name in a model group. All content-tags starts with a particle-id.
    • path - an array of tags used to navigate from a tag-object-pair in an XmlData infoset to some descendant tag-object-pair. There are two types of paths: map-paths, and copy-paths. Future release might add additional path types. The String format of a path is: 
       
         /step1/step2 ...
      where each step is a tag in path-name format.
    • path-name - A tag as it appears in a path. Path-names are similar to full-names but include additional information such as index or an indirect-qualifier. It may also be an iterator-tag rather than a full-name. The path-name format is: 
          ncName#namespaceURI[index]{indirect-qualifier}
      • particle-id, ncName, and namespace have they same meaning as they do with full-names; when used in a copy-path, the full-name may be replaced an iterator-tag and is called a name-iterator
      • index - is an array offset starting at 0; when used in a copy-path, it may also be an iterator-tag and is called an index-iterator
      • indirect-qualifier - is a content-tag used when creating indirect-item; when using copy-paths, it may also be an iterator-tag and is called a qualifier-iterator
    • qualifier-iterator - an iterator-tag used as a place holder for an indirect-qualifier in a path-step as used by XmlDataCopy.
    • repeating-values - the value of schema particle or group that has maxOccurs > 1 is represented as an array of values in the XmlData infoset.
    • simple-value - a Java String. An empty simple-value is represented as an empty String (never as a Java null)
    • substitution-item - a specialized IData structure used to represent the XML infoset tag and content that is replacing the head of a substitution group. Substitution-items are always paired with a substitution-tag. Substitution-items are always represented as an IData containing a single tag-object-pair. The tag is always an element-tag that is a member of the substitution group and the object is always the content associated with the substituted element. The object is always a scalar is either a simple-value, group-value, or complex-value,
    • substitution-tag - a String tag that is paired with a substitution-item. Substitution-tags correspond to the head of a substitution group and substitution-items correspond to the substituted tag and content for the head of the substitution groups. A substitution-tag is an indirect-tag because there is no actual tag in the XML instance with that name. It is paired with a substitution-item that contains the actual tag and content as it appears in the XML infoset.
      Its form is {particleId}*substitution-ncName#namespace where:
      • particleId -- the particle-id
      • ncName -- the XML local name of the substitution group head
      • namespace -- the XML namespace of the substitution group head
    • tag - a String used as the tag in a tag-object-pair in an XmlData infoset. They typically correspond to an element tag or an attribute tag from a source XML infoset, though they have other uses as well. XmlData tags preserve the namespace as part of the tag using a format called the full-name form. The full-name format is: 
          ncName#namespaceURI
      If the tag does not have a namespace qualifier, the # separator is also excluded. Tags never appear alone. They are always part of a tag-object-pair in a group-value or as part of a tag-object-pair in an attribute-set. When a tag is used in a group-value, it also has a particle-id prefix that identifies the relative positioned of like-named particle in the corresponding schema model group. Tags that have a particle-id prefix are called content-tags. The full-name format of a content-tag includes the particle-d and is: 
          {particle-id}ncName#namespace
      When a tag is used in an attribute-set it does not have particle-id prefix. An XmlData infoset contains many types of tags: element-tags, attributes-tags, group-tags, substitution-tags, and any-tags. Element-tags and attribute-tags correspond directly to the element tags and attribute tags in the source XML infoset. Group-tags, any-tags, and substitution-tags do not correspond with tags present in the source XML infoset. Instead they correspond to XML schema structures that are created in the XmlData infoset and contains the additional information that describes model group, any wildcards, and substitution groups. Element-tags, group-tags, any-tags, and substitution-tags all content-tags because they correspond to group models or particle in a schema content model, and therefore can appear more than once in a model and require the particle-id for unique identification. In addition to the full-name format that appears in XmlData infosets, there is also the path-name format. The path-name format includes additional properties and is in the form: 
          {particle-id}ncName#namespaceURI[index]{indirect-qualifier}
      The path-name format is used in map-paths and copy-paths. They provide additional information when accessing repeating values or creating indirect-items.
    • tag-object-pair - a member of a group-value or attribute-set (essentially a key/value pair in an IData where the key is an XmlData tag and the object is either a value, or an indirect-item, or an array of values, or an array of indirect-items). When paired with an attribute-tag in an attribute-set, the object is always a simple-value
    • type-tag - a tag used to name a type. It is not a content-tag because it has no particle-id. Like attribute-tags, they consist of an ncName and namespace and in that regard, resemble an attribute-tag.
    • value - an XmlData infoset value created from a corresponding XML infoset value. An XmlData infoset value is typically a String when it corresponds to XML infoset element that has no child elements or attributes, and is an IData when it corresponds to XML infoset element which has child elements or attributes. The XmlData infoset does not currently support mixed content. There are three types of values:
      • simple-value - a String; it may appear as element value, attribute value, complex-value-content, an any-item value, or an item in a substitution-items tag-item pair
      • group-value - an IData; it may appear as an element value, a nested group-value paired with a group-tag, complex-value-content, an any-item value, or an item in a substitution-item's tag-item pair.
      • complex-value an IData with optional attribute-set and complex-value-content; may appear as an element value in a group-value, an any-item value, or as an item in a substitution-item's tag-item pair
    • value-tag -- the tag that is paired with a value. Typically the value-tag is identical to the content-tag (for element-tags and group-tags). However, if the content-tag is a substitution-tag or an any-tag, the value-tag is the tag embedded in the indirect-tem. In other words, the value's tag is derived from the any-item's *ncName and *namespace fields, or from the substitution-item's first and only child (the substituted tag and value)

        Makes a copy of any valid XmlData value. Valid XmlData values must be Strings, String[]s, iData, IData[]s, or Object[]s containing one of the preceding item. Nulls are not valid. Object[]s containing other Object arrays are not valid.
        Parameters:
        in - make a copy of the input Object
        Returns:

        public static com.wm.data.IData createAnyItem(XmlDataSubstitutionTag tag,
                                              com.wm.data.IData substitutionItem)
        Create an any-item document with a substitution-item nested within it. An any-item IData document is created having *ncName and *namespace fields paired with values derived from the supplied XmlDataSubstitutionTag. The content must a properly formatted substitutionItem-item. See createSubstitutionItem(XmlDataElementTag, Object)
        Parameters:

        Throws:
        XmlDataException.ArgumentError - when the content is not a valid substitution-item.

      • createAttributes

        public static com.wm.data.IData createAttributes(java.lang.Object... pairs)
        Create the attribute-set for a complex-value. This result is typically used as an argument to the createComplexValue(IData, Object) method. The result is an IData with members that are attribute-tags paired with String values.
        Parameters:
        pairs - pairs of alternating XmlDataAttributeTags and Strings attribute value.
        Returns:
        IData collection of attribute/value items
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.FormatError - when an odd number of arguments is passed
        XmlDataException.UnsupportedType - when an attribute value is not a String
        XmlDataException.TagAndContentConflict - when a pair starts with anything except an XmlDataAttributeTag

      • createComplexValue

        public static com.wm.data.IData createComplexValue()
        Create a new empty complex-value. The complex-value created by this method has no attributes and no complex-value-content. The content may be set using the XmlDataCursor.setContent(Object, int...) and XmlDataCursor.setAttributes(IData, int...) methods. Complex-values should be used only as element values, never as attribute values. At present, this method creates an empty IData. However, it is preferable to use this method to create the empty IData rather than using an IData factory because future XmlData implementations may impose additional constraints on complex-values.
        Returns:
        an empty IData object

      • createComplexValue

        public static com.wm.data.IData createComplexValue(com.wm.data.IData attributes,
                                                   java.lang.Object itemContent)
        Create a new populated complex-value. A complex-value is an IData object with a specific structure. Its structure may be one of the following:
        • a completely empty IData object: no *attributes, *groups, or *simple children
        • an IData object with a single *attributes field with optionally either a *simple field (simple content) or a single {1}*group tag
        • a single *{1}group tag with array content
        The content may be set using the XmlDataCursor.setContent(Object, int...) and XmlDataCursor.setAttributes(IData, int...) methods. Complex-values should be used only as element values, never as attribute values. If the content is a non-repeating group-value and no attributes argument is provided, an empty IData is used as the attributes argument. The complex-value is populated with the specified attributes value (if not null) and is populated with group content if content is an IData, or simple content using a *simple tag if content is a String.
        Parameters:
        attributes - the attribute values, typically constructed by a call to XmlData.createAttributes
        itemContent - the complex-value's complex-value-content (either a String for simple content, or group content.
        Returns:
        an IData formatted as a complex-value
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.UnsupportedType - when value is not an IData or String

        Create a list of empty IDatas. Each member has a new, empty IData instance.
        Parameters:
        size - the number of entries
        Returns:
        initialized IData[]

      • createGroupValue

        public static com.wm.data.IData createGroupValue(java.lang.Object... pairs)
        Create a new group-value. Group content may contain any number of elements, *any wildcard, *substitution, or other *group content. At present, this method returns an empty IData if no argument pairs are specified. However, it is preferable to use this method to create an empty group rather than using an IData factory because future XmlData implementations may impose additional constraints on group content. This method accepts a list of alternating XmlDataContentTags and content objects. The returned IData is initialized with those tag/object pairs. Suitable classes of XmlDataContentTags are XmlDataElementTag, XmlDataAnyTag, XMlDataGroupTag, and XmlDataSubstitutionTag. Group-values should be used only as element values directly or complex-value content, never as attribute values.
        Parameters:
        pairs - possibly empty Object[] where even members are instances of XmlDataContentTag subclasses and odd members are content objects suitable for their corresponding tag that immediately precedes them.
        Returns:
        IData document optionally populated with name/value pairs
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.ArgumentError - when an odd number of arguments is passed
        XmlDataException.TagAndContentConflict - when the first member of a pair is not an XmlDataContentTag
        XmlDataException.UnsupportedType - when the second member of a pair is not valid XmlData content: String, String[], IData, IData[], or Object[]

        Returns:

        Throws:

      • equalTo

        public static boolean equalTo(java.lang.Object objA,
                              java.lang.Object objB)
        Tests equality of two XmlData formatted objects. This method checks the equality of Strings, IDatas, String[], IData[], Object[], and any nested IDatas. This method can loop indefinitely because it does not check for recursive content. XmlData must never be recursive.
        Parameters:
        objA - the first Object
        objB - the second Object
        Returns:
        true if they are equal

      • getComplexValueContent

        public static java.lang.Object getComplexValueContent(com.wm.data.IData complexValue)
        Finds the content of a complex-value. It returns the content associated with the *simple tag or the solitary {1}*group tag or null if neither is present (only attributes present or the input value is an empty IData). Empty IData input returns null even though isComplexValue(Object) returns true because there is no {1}*group or *simple tag with associated content. By convention, empty IData normally represent empty groups rather than empty complex values. This method is similar to the XmlDataCursor.getComplexValueContent(int...) method, but it operates on a free-standing value, rather than a value that is specified by a cursor.
        Parameters:
        complexValue - the value from which the *simple or top-level *group value is returned
        Returns:
        the content which is either null, a simple string, an IData, or an IData[].
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.FormatError - when the parent is not a complex-value.

      • getContent

        public static java.lang.Object getContent(java.lang.Object value)
        Returns the content portion of a value. The content does not include attributes. For non-complex values, the value itself is returned. For complex values, the result obtained by getComplexValueContent(IData)} is returned. If the complex value has no content, null is returned; but if the complex value can be interpreted as an empty group, the empty group is returned (an empty IDta rather than null); If the content is a repeating group, an IData[] is returned.
        Parameters:
        value - the input value
        Returns:
        the value of the input

      • getXmlDataCursor

        public static XmlDataCursor getXmlDataCursor(com.wm.data.IData group)
        Create an return return an XmlDataCursor on the specified group-value. In theory, any IData object can be passed as an argument. However, if the IData object does not conform to the standard XmlData format, errors and unpredictable results are possible. Only IData objects created using the XmlData and XmlDataCursor methods should be passed.
        Parameters:
        group - the IData object for which an XmlDatCursor is created. This should only be an IData intended for use as group-value.
        Returns:
        an XmlDataCursor in the unpositioned state

      • getXmlDataTreeCursor

        public static XmlDataTreeCursor getXmlDataTreeCursor(com.wm.data.IData group)
        Create and return an XmlDataTreeCursor on the specified group-value. In theory, any IData object can be passed as an argument. However, if the IData object does not conform to the standard XmlData format, errors and unpredictable results are possible. Only IData objects abd their children created using the XmlData and XmlDataTreeCursor methods should be passed.
        Parameters:
        group - a cursor positioned on the item for which a tree cursor is created
        Returns:
        the tree cursor

      • internNames

        public static void internNames(boolean b)
        Determines when XmlDataTags are interned Strings
        Parameters:
        b - if true, names are interned Strings; otherwise names are discrete strings.

      • isAny

        public static boolean isAny(XmlDataContentTag tag)
        Returns true of the specified tag is a *any wildcard tag
        Parameters:
        tag - the tag that is tested
        Returns:
        true if the tag is a *any tag.

      • isComplexValue

        public static boolean isComplexValue(java.lang.Object value)
        Determines if a value is a complex-value. If the argument object is not an IData false is returned. This method verifies that the argument contains: *attributes with or with or without *group or *simple, solitary *simple, or solitary {1}*group tag with repeating content. An empty IData is also considered a complex-value because one of the above-mentioned entities could be added to and still remain a complex-value. A solitary *group tag with non-repeating content is considered a group-value rather than a complex-value. The isGroupValue(Object) method also returns true if the value is a completely empty IData. This means that an empty IData will return true for both isComplexValue() and isGroupValue().
        Parameters:
        value - the value to be tested
        Returns:
        true if the value is an empty IData or contains one or more of: *attributes, *simple content, or a solitary {1}*group tag with repeating content.

      • isEmpty

        public static boolean isEmpty(java.lang.Object content)
        Return true if content is empty. This method works at the content level (for example, the content returned by getContent(Object) Empty is defined as follows:
        • empty String
        • empty IData
        • list of empty Strings and/or IDatas (Java null not allowed
        Parameters:
        content - the content to test
        Returns:
        true if empty

      • isGroupValue

        public static boolean isGroupValue(java.lang.Object group)
        Determines if a value is a group-value. If the argument object is not an IData false is returned. This method verifies that the argument contains no *attributes, *simple, or solitary {1}*group tag with repeating content. An empty IData is also considered a. The isComplexValue(Object) method also returns true if the value is a completely empty IData. This means that an empty IData will return true for both isComplexValue() and isGroupValue().
        Parameters:
        group - the value to be tested
        Returns:
        true if the values is an empty IData or contains no attributes, simple content, or a solitary {1}*group tag with repeating content.

      • isIntern

        public static boolean isIntern()
        Indicates whether XmlDataTags are interned Strings
        Returns:
        true if tags are interned

      • isSubstitution

        public static boolean isSubstitution(XmlDataContentTag tag)

        Parameters:
        tag - the tag that is tested
        Returns:
        true if the specified tag is a substitution tag

      • makeRepeating

        public static java.lang.Object makeRepeating(java.lang.Object val)
        Converts a scalar item into a repeating value with a single value
        Parameters:
        val - the value to be converted, Must be of type String or IData
        Returns:
        the appropriate array type

      • setAnyItemTag

        public static void setAnyItemTag(com.wm.data.IData anyItem,
                                 XmlDataContentTag key)
        Sets the ncName and namespace properties of an any-item.
        Parameters:
        anyItem - the any-item. The setAnyValueKey method is preferable to this method. This method is ued only when directly modifying the any-item fields regardless of content (such as a substitution group).
        key - the XmlDataContentTag that provides the ncName and the XML namespace URI
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.FormatError - if the any document has an invalid structure

      • setAnyItemObject

        public static void setAnyItemObject(com.wm.data.IData anyItem,
                                    java.lang.Object indirectItem)
        Sets the *value property of a any-item.
        Parameters:
        anyItem - An any-item
        indirectItem - the item assigned to the *value property.
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.FormatError - if indirectItem is null, or the IData cannot be formatted properly.

      • setAnyItemValue

        public static void setAnyItemValue(com.wm.data.IData anyItem,
                                   java.lang.Object indirectItem)
        Set the *value property in an any-item
        Parameters:
        anyItem - the IData object that is formatted as an any-item
        indirectItem - the value to set in the any-tem *value property

      • setAnyItemValueTag

        public static void setAnyItemValueTag(com.wm.data.IData anyItem,
                                      XmlDataElementTag name)
        Set the ncName and namespace for properties of an any-item. This method behaves exactly like setAnyItemTag(IData, XmlDataContentTag) except when the content is a substitution-item. In that situation, the key of the value in the substitution-item is changed. When working with content, this method is typically preferable to setAnyItemKey because it sets the key for the logical content regardless of whether it's a element or a substitution group.
        Parameters:
        anyItem - the value of the element wildcard
        name - the XmlDataElementTag naming the wildcard element
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.FormatError - if anyItem is not an IData

      • setAttributes

        public static void setAttributes(com.wm.data.IData value,
                                 com.wm.data.IData attributes)
        For a complex values, sets the attributes, for example, attribute created using createAttributes(Object...)
        Parameters:
        value - the value for which attributes are set
        attributes - the attributes

      • setComplexValueContent

        public static void setComplexValueContent(com.wm.data.IData value,
                                          java.lang.Object content)
        Sets the content portion of a complex value. For String content, the content is associated with the *simple tag. For IData or IData[] conner, the content is associated with the {1}*group tag.
        Parameters:
        value - the IData complex-value into which the content is inserted
        content - the content (For example, as returned by getComplexValueContent(IData)
        Throws:
        XmlDataException.FormatError - if the value is not in complex value format

      • setInstanceProp

        public static void setInstanceProp(com.wm.data.IData data,
                                   XmlDataElementTag tag,
                                   java.lang.String xsiTag,
                                   java.lang.String xsiValue)
        Set the xsi prop declaration for a given XmlData element with a non-repeating value. A value of null deletes the declaration if it exists.
        Parameters:
        data - the IData parent of the tag for which the xsi property is being set
        tag - the element-tag for which the property is being set
        xsiTag - the xsi tag being set
        xsiValue - the xsi tag value

      • setInstanceProp

        public static void setInstanceProp(com.wm.data.IData data,
                                   XmlDataElementTag tag,
                                   int index,
                                   java.lang.String xsiTag,
                                   java.lang.String xsiValue)
        Set the xsi prop declaration for a given XmlData element with repeating values. A value value of null deletes the declaration if it exists.
        Parameters:
        data - the IData parent of the tag for which the xsi property is being set
        tag - the element-tag for which the property is being set
        index - the offset into the array of repeating values
        xsiTag - the xsi tag being set
        xsiValue - the xsi tag value

      • setNamespacePrefix

        public static void setNamespacePrefix(com.wm.data.IData data,
                                      XmlDataContentTag tag,

                                      java.lang.String namespace)

        data - is the IData parent of the tag for which the namespace prefix is set
        tag - is the element-tag for which the namespace prefix is set
        prefix - is the prefix which is being defined
        namespace - is the namespace assigned to the prefix

        namespace - is the namespace assigned to the prefix

      • setOrAppendObject

        public static void setOrAppendObject(com.wm.data.IData groupValue,
                                     XmlDataContentTag tag,
                                     java.lang.Object value)
        A convenience method to set the object at the specified tag without explicitly obtaining and destroying a cursor. If the tag does not exist, the tag and object are appended to the end of the group-value.
        Parameters:
        groupValue - the containing the tag
        tag - the specified tag
        value - the Object to be set

                                            java.lang.Object content)

      • valueType

        public static java.lang.String valueType(java.lang.Object value)
        Return the type name of a non-repeating value. Returns "simple", "group", or "complex" But an empty IData can satisfy isComplexValue() or isGroupValue(), so return "empty." Otherwise return "unsupported".
        Parameters:
        value - the input: simple-value, group-value, complex-value; typically an Object returned by getValue()
        Returns:
        the type: "simple", "group", "complex", "empty", or "error".
